title-group.article-title: Discovering Creativity in Necessity: Organizational Ingenuity under Institutional Constraints

body.p: Joseph Lampel (Cass Business School, City University London)
Benson Honig (DeGroote School of Business, McMaster University)
Israel Drori (College of Management, School of Business Administration
and Faculty of Management, Tel-Aviv University)

sec.title: Deadline: February 28th 2012
sec.p: The construction of creativity in organizations continues to puzzle scholars. Creativity is often associated with organizational spaces where rules and boundaries are weak if non-existent, and by the same token is considered to decline where they are strong and pervasive. This dichotomy, between organizational freedom and necessity, results in opposing images of creativity and its absence: On the one hand we have romantic images of entrepreneurs asserting creativity by breaking rules and transcending boundaries, and on the other institutionalized managers constrained by rules and prevented by boundaries from exercising creativity.

The interplay of freedom and necessity in organizations, however, is more nuanced. Most organizational actors have to operate both within and through existing rules and boundaries to effect creative solutions to existing problems. To meet the challenge of the situation these actors develop a set of skills, social tactics, and mental orientation that express “organizational ingenuity”: the ability to create innovative solutions within structural constraints using limited resources and imaginative problem solving.

sec.title: Organizational Ingenuity as Creative Managerial Entrepreneurship
sec.p: Building on extant work, we claim that organizational ingenuity within institutional constraints is not only a confrontation between change and inertia, it can also be a creative adaptation or reformulation of institutional constraints that are either intrinsic or extrinsic to the structure and strategy of the organization in question. Seen in this perspective, organizational actors working within the constraints embedded in the legitimate logic of the organization are motivated to find creative solutions to existing problems, or to develop new systems that provide innovative opportunities. Thus, actors employ creative actions to drive organizational ingenuity which enables re-conceiving the basic purpose, practices and ethos of the organizations in which he or she works.

Organizational ingenuity applies to single organizations navigating their environment, but also to organizational populations seeking to change the institutional frameworks that define and constrain their environment. In this respect, organizational ingenuity is a societal level capability that is behind many of the governance and organizational innovations that have shaped our current economic, social, and political realities, and a crucial part of the innovations needed to address the current challenges facing a world in transition (Courpasson, Arellano-Gault, Brown and Lounsbury, 2008).

Organizational ingenuity is therefore practiced at different organizational, sectoral, national, and international. It is practiced within the organization at the interface between individual, team, project, and business unit levels (Bundy, 2002; Okhuysen and Bechky, 2009), but is also employed externally by the organization as it engages with its regulatory and societal interactions. In these contexts organizational ingenuity combines both dissention and cooperation to game and tilt organizational and societal power in the pursuit of limited or global goals (see Couprasson and Clegg, 2006). Its practices therefore reflect the governance system in which it is embedded, but this embeddedness is used to advantage by co-opting, coordinating, and whenever possible drawing on organizational slack to effect change (March and Simon, 1963; Donaldson, 2001). Accordingly, the special issue addresses institutional rationality that combines the micro-processes of actors’ practices, and the macro structures and cultural frames that organize meanings (see Lounsbury, 2008). It explores the interaction between creativity and institutional processes that give rise to individual and collective expressions of organizational ingenuity.

With the above in mind, the key questions that this Special Issue therefore addresses are: Under what conditions does organizational ingenuity emerge? How do social actors innovate within the constraints of their institutional processes, and how do they use institutional processes to alter the institutions in which they operate?

sec.title: Possible Topics
sec.p: This special issue is intended to encourage scholarly interest in the more contextual and practice oriented aspects of organizational ingenuity and creativity. We welcome submissions from a variety of disciplines and point of views. In particular, we are interested in submissions that relate to the way organizational actors employ creative tools in their plight for change. We also encourage submissions that can bridge the major gap between ‘structure and agency’ in the creative process, as well as the tension between the accommodation of structure versus its reformulation and bypassing, using various levels of analysis and addressing multiple fields, to explain the central role of actors in constituting and employing organizational creativity for the purpose of promoting change. With this in mind we encourage submissions that focus on the following issues:

list-item.p: Papers that examine the nature and dynamics of organizational ingenuity
Papers that examine organizational ingenuity in different kinds of organizations such as bureaucracies, post bureaucracies, collegial organizations, and collectivist organizations.
Papers that examine organizational ingenuity by top, middle, and first-line management.
Papers that examine organizational ingenuity in projects and temporary organizations.
Papers that examine organizational ingenuity in different countries and cultures.
Papers that examine formal and informal uses of organizational ingenuity.
Papers that examine the interaction between individual and organizational ingenuity.
Papers that explore the organizational processes that facilitate ingenuity and creativity, with particular attention on how these processes shape organization’s values and managerial norms.
Papers that examine whether organizational ingenuity can become transmittable knowledge.
Papers that examine organizational factors that favor or suppress the emergence and effectiveness of organizational ingenuity.
Papers that examines the interaction of organizational ingenuity with business innovation.
Papers that examine the interaction of organizational ingenuity with entrepreneurial action.
Papers that examine how creative organizational entrepreneurs deal with resource constraints.

Papers that explore how organizational entrepreneurs enact creative processes, act as enablers, and react to the dynamics along different fields, industries or organizations (e.g. new-old, small-big)?
Papers that examine how creative and ingenious entrepreneurs deal with the organization’s interaction with the environment.
Papers that examine the interaction of organizational ingenuity with power and politics in organizations.
Papers that examine organizational ingenuity by groups and teams.
Papers that examine the empirical and methodological problems of studying creative organizational ingenuity.

sec.title: Submissions
sec.p: Please submit papers through the journal’s online submission system, SAGE track. Please visit SAGE track http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/orgstudies, create your user account (if you have not done so already), and on “Manuscript Type” choose the following: SI: Discovering Creativity in Necessity: Organizational Ingenuity under Institutional Constraints.

All papers that will enter the reviewing process will be double-blindly reviewed following the journal’s normal review process and criteria. Any papers which may be accepted but will not be included in the Special Issue will be published in an ordinary issue at a later point in time. For further information please contact any of the Guest Editors for this Special Issue: lampel@city.ac.uk, israeld@colman.ac.il, bhonig@wlu.ca
